Notation:
≈D\overset{D}{\approx}≈D means “asymptotically follows the distribution”
∼iid.\overset{iid.}{\sim}∼iid. means “are independently and identically distributed”
Capital letters XXX are random variables, and lower-case xxx are their (observed) values.
Bold letters X,x\mathbf{X},\mathbf{x}X,x are vector/multi-dimensional random variables and their (observed) values.

Handwavy Estimation

The Delta Method

Big idea: the delta method estimates the mean and variance of some function f(X)f(X)f(X). If XXX is asymptotically Gaussian, so is the estimate.

  • Suppose there is a distribution DDD with mean μ\muμ and variance σ2\sigma^{2}σ2, and we want to estimate some function g(μ)g(\mu)g(μ) from an iid. sample X1,…,Xn∼DX_{1}, \dots, X_{n}\sim DX1​,…,Xn​∼D.
  • The Taylor expansion of g(Xˉ)g(\bar{X})g(Xˉ) around μ\muμ is: g(Xˉ)=g(μ)+(Xˉ−μ)g′(μ)+O((Xˉ−μ)2)g(\bar{X})=g(\mu)+ (\bar{X}-\mu)g'(\mu)+O((\bar{X}-\mu)^{2})g(Xˉ)=g(μ)+(Xˉ−μ)g′(μ)+O((Xˉ−μ)2)where (Xˉ−μ)=O(n−1/2)(\bar{X}-\mu)=O(n^{-1 / 2})(Xˉ−μ)=O(n−1/2) by the CLT.
  • Hence the delta method linearizes the expansion to be g(Xˉ)≈g(μ)+(Xˉ−μ)g′(μ)g(\bar{X})\approx g(\mu)+ (\bar{X}-\mu)g'(\mu)g(Xˉ)≈g(μ)+(Xˉ−μ)g′(μ) and gives the estimates E[g(Xˉ)]≈g(μ)Var(g(Xˉ))≈Var((Xˉ−μ)g′(μ))=Var(Xˉ)g′(μ)2=σ2ng′(μ)2\begin{align*} \mathbb{E}[g(\bar{X})]&\approx g(\mu)\\ \mathrm{Var}(g(\bar{X}))&\approx \mathrm{Var}\left((\bar{X}-\mu)g'(\mu)\right)=\mathrm{Var}(\bar{X})g'(\mu)^{2}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}g'(\mu)^{2} \end{align*}E[g(Xˉ)]Var(g(Xˉ))​≈g(μ)≈Var((Xˉ−μ)g′(μ))=Var(Xˉ)g′(μ)2=nσ2​g′(μ)2​
  • Since the estimate of g(Xˉ)g(\bar{X})g(Xˉ) is a linear transformation of (Xˉ−μ)(\bar{X}-\mu)(Xˉ−μ), and (Xˉ−μ)≈DN(0,σ2/n)(\bar{X}-\mu) \overset{D}{\approx} N(0, \sigma^{2} / n)(Xˉ−μ)≈DN(0,σ2/n) by the CLT, the asymptotic distribution of g(Xˉ)g(\bar{X})g(Xˉ) is also normal: g(Xˉ)≈DN(g(μ),σ2ng′(μ)2)g(\bar{X}) \overset{D}{\approx} N\left(g(\mu),\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}g'(\mu)^{2}\right)g(Xˉ)≈DN(g(μ),nσ2​g′(μ)2)and the two parameters are the asymptotic mean/variance.
  • In general, given a variable YYY with E[Y]=μ\mathbb{E}[Y]=\muE[Y]=μ, the delta method estimates its function g(Y)g(Y)g(Y) to have E[g(Y)]≈g(μ)Var(g(Y))≈Var(Y)g′(μ)2\begin{align*} \mathbb{E}[g(Y)]&\approx g(\mu)\\ \mathrm{Var}(g(Y))&\approx \mathrm{Var}(Y)g'(\mu)^{2} \end{align*}E[g(Y)]Var(g(Y))​≈g(μ)≈Var(Y)g′(μ)2​this does not assume that YYY is normal (even asymptotically).
  • Furthermore, if Y≈DN(μ,σ2)Y \overset{D}{\approx} N(\mu,\sigma^{2})Y≈DN(μ,σ2), then the asymptotic distribution of its function g(Y)g(Y)g(Y) is g(Y)≈DN(g(μ),σ2ng′(μ)2)g(Y) \overset{D}{\approx} N\left(g(\mu),\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n}g'(\mu)^{2}\right)g(Y)≈DN(g(μ),nσ2​g′(μ)2)

Order Statistics

  • Given data Xi=xiX_{i}=x_{i}Xi​=xi​ for i=1,…,ni=1, \dots, ni=1,…,n, their rrrth order statistic is X(r)=x(r)X_{(r)}=x_{(r)}X(r)​=x(r)​, the rrrth smallest observed value.
    • In particular, X(1)=min⁡{Xi}X_{(1)}=\min \{ X_{i} \}X(1)​=min{Xi​}, and X(n)=max⁡{Xi}X_{(n)}=\max \{ X_{i} \}X(n)​=max{Xi​}.
  • The median is M={X(n+1)if n=2m+1 odd12(X(m)+X(m+1))if n=2m evenM=\begin{cases} X_{(n+1)} & \text{if $n=2m+1$ odd} \\ \frac{1}{2}(X_{(m)}+X_{(m+1)}) & \text{if $n=2m$ even} \end{cases}M={X(n+1)​21​(X(m)​+X(m+1)​)​if n=2m+1 oddif n=2m even​
  • If the iid. data have cdf. and pdf. Xi∼F,fX_{i} \sim F,fXi​∼F,f, then their order statistics have distributions: X(r)∼f(r)(x)=n!(r−1)!(n−r)!F(x)r−1[1−F(x)]n−rf(x)X_{(r)} \sim f_{(r)}(x)=\frac{n!}{(r-1)!(n-r)!}F(x)^{r-1} [1-F(x)]^{n-r}f(x)X(r)​∼f(r)​(x)=(r−1)!(n−r)!n!​F(x)r−1[1−F(x)]n−rf(x)

Proof: note that F(r)(x)=P(X(r)≤x)=P(at least r of Xi≤x)F_{(r)}(x)= \Bbb{P}(X_{(r)} \le x)=\Bbb{P}(\text{at least } r \text{ of }X_{i}\le x)F(r)​(x)=P(X(r)​≤x)=P(at least r of Xi​≤x).
Hence F(r)−F(r+1)=P(r of Xi≤x, (n−r) of Xi>x)=(nr)F(x)r[1−F(x)]n−r\begin{align*}F_{(r)}-F_{(r+1)}&= \Bbb{P}(r \text{ of }X_{i}\le x,\, (n-r)\text{ of }X_{i} > x)\\ &=\begin{pmatrix}n \\ r\end{pmatrix}F(x)^{r}[1-F(x)]^{n-r} \end{align*}F(r)​−F(r+1)​​=P(r of Xi​≤x,(n−r) of Xi​>x)=(nr​)F(x)r[1−F(x)]n−r​Then differentiate and use induction to prove the result.

  • Order statistics of the uniform distribution U[0,1]U[0,1]U[0,1]: for an iid. sample U1,…,Un∼U[0,1]U_{1}, \dots, U_{n} \sim U[0,1]U1​,…,Un​∼U[0,1], their order statistics U(r)U_{(r)}U(r)​ satisfy: E[U(r)]=rn+1Var(U(r))=r(n+1)(n+2)(1−rn+1)\begin{align*} \mathbb{E}[U_{(r)}]&=\frac{r}{n+1}\\ \mathrm{Var}(U_{(r)})&= \frac{r}{(n+1)(n+2)}\left( 1-\frac{r}{n+1} \right) \end{align*}E[U(r)​]Var(U(r)​)​=n+1r​=(n+1)(n+2)r​(1−n+1r​)​

Q-Q Plots: Theory

Big idea: Q-Q plots compare the order statistics of the observed sample to the order statistics of a known distribution; if the sample indeed follows that distribution, the plot should look like a line.

  • If X∼FX \sim FX∼F, where F(x)F(x)F(x) is a strictly increasing cdf., then Y=F(X)∼U[0,1]Y=F(X) \sim U[0,1]Y=F(X)∼U[0,1].

Proof: P(Y≤y)=P(F(X)≤y)=P(X≤F−1(y))=F(F−1(y))=y\Bbb{P}(Y \le y)=\Bbb{P}(F(X) \le y)=\Bbb{P}(X \le F^{-1}(y))= F(F^{-1}(y))=yP(Y≤y)=P(F(X)≤y)=P(X≤F−1(y))=F(F−1(y))=ywhere the inverse exists since FFF is strictly increasing. Hence Y∼U[0,1]Y \sim U[0,1]Y∼U[0,1].

  • Therefore, using the delta method to estimate X(r)=F−1(U(r))X_{(r)}=F^{-1}(U_{(r)})X(r)​=F−1(U(r)​) from U(r)U_{(r)}U(r)​ gives E[F−1(U(r))]≈F−1(E[U(r)])=F−1(rn+1)\mathbb{E}[F^{-1}(U_{(r)})]\approx F^{-1}(\mathbb{E}[U_{(r)}])=F^{-1}\left( \frac{r}{n+1} \right)E[F−1(U(r)​)]≈F−1(E[U(r)​])=F−1(n+1r​)with variance Var(F−1(U(r)))=Var(U(r))undefined→0⋅[dF−1(u)du∣u=rn+1]2→0\mathrm{Var}(F^{-1}(U_{(r)}))=\underbrace{\mathrm{Var}(U_{(r)})}_{\to 0}\cdot {\left[\frac{dF^{-1}(u)}{du}\Big|_{u=\frac{r}{n+1}}\right]^{2}} \to 0Var(F−1(U(r)​))=→0Var(U(r)​)​​⋅[dudF−1(u)​∣∣​u=n+1r​​]2→0we expect X(r)X_{(r)}X(r)​ to be close to F−1(rn+1)F^{-1}\left( \frac{r}{n+1} \right)F−1(n+1r​) when nnn large, hence forming a near-perfect line when plotting them against eachother.

  • The Q-Q plot then plots the observed order statistics x(1),…,x(n)x_{(1)}, \dots, x_{(n)}x(1)​,…,x(n)​ against F−1(1n+1),…,F−1(nn+1)F^{-1}\left( \frac{1}{n+1} \right), \dots, F^{-1}\left( \frac{n}{n+1} \right)F−1(n+11​),…,F−1(n+1n​), the expected order of a distribution FFF.

    • Hence, if the points are roughly linear, we can conclude that the data do follow the distribution; otherwise, the distribution would be a bad model.

Q-Q Plots in Practice

  • If the cdf. FFF is known, we can directly compute d(r)=F−1(rn+1)d_{(r)}=F^{-1}\left( \frac{r}{n+1} \right)d(r)​=F−1(n+1r​). However, in practice, the parameters are unknown, so we do not have FFF.

  • Instead, we need a linear relation that holds true for a whole family of distributions Xi∼F(θ)X_{i} \sim F(\theta)Xi​∼F(θ), where θ\thetaθ is the unknown parameter(s).

    • Different θ\thetaθ should only affect the slope and intersept of the line.

  • We start with the fact that F(x(r),θ)≈rn+1F(x_{(r)}, \theta) \approx\frac{r}{n+1}F(x(r)​,θ)≈n+1r​, and rearrange to find the linear relation x(r)=α(θ)⋅g(rn+1)+β(θ)x_{(r)}=\alpha(\theta)\cdot g\left(\frac{r}{n+1}\right)+\beta(\theta)x(r)​=α(θ)⋅g(n+1r​)+β(θ)for some ggg independent of θ\thetaθ; different θ\thetaθ should only affect the slope α(θ)\alpha(\theta)α(θ) and intersept β(θ)\beta(\theta)β(θ) of the line.

  • The normal Q-Q plot: if X1,…,n∼iid.N(μ,σ2)X_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(\mu, \sigma^2)X1,…,n​∼iid.N(μ,σ2), normalizing X(r)X_{(r)}X(r)​ gives X(r)−μσ∼N(0,1)⟹Φ(X(r)−μσ)≈rn+1\frac{X_{(r)}-\mu}{\sigma}\sim N(0,1) \Longrightarrow \Phi\left(\frac{X_{(r)}-\mu}{\sigma}\right) \approx \frac{r}{n+1}σX(r)​−μ​∼N(0,1)⟹Φ(σX(r)​−μ​)≈n+1r​giving the linear relationship x(r)≈σΦ−1(rn+1)+μx_{(r)} \approx \sigma\Phi^{-1}\left( \frac{r}{n+1} \right)+\mux(r)​≈σΦ−1(n+1r​)+μtherefore plotting x(r)x_{(r)}x(r)​ against Φ−1(rn+1)\Phi^{-1}\left( \frac{r}{n+1} \right)Φ−1(n+1r​) should give a linear relationship.

  • For exponential distributions X1,…,n∼iid.exp⁡(λ)X_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} \exp(\lambda)X1,…,n​∼iid.exp(λ), the equation F(x(r),λ)≈rn+1F(x_{(r)},\lambda)\approx \frac{r}{n+1}F(x(r)​,λ)≈n+1r​ becomes 1−e−λx(r)≈rn+11-e^{-\lambda x_{(r)}} \approx \frac{r}{n+1}1−e−λx(r)​≈n+1r​so solving for x(r)x_{(r)}x(r)​ gives x(r)≈−1λlog⁡(1−rn+1)x_{(r)} \approx -\frac{1}{\lambda}\log\left( 1-\frac{r}{n+1} \right)x(r)​≈−λ1​log(1−n+1r​)therefore plotting x(r)x_{(r)}x(r)​ against log⁡(1−rn+1)\log\left( 1-\frac{r}{n+1} \right)log(1−n+1r​) should give a linear relationship.

Information and the MLE

Information

  • The (observed) information of a parameter θ\thetaθ is the quantity J(θ)=−∂2l∂θ2J(\theta)=- \frac{\partial^{2} l}{\partial \theta^{2}}J(θ)=−∂θ2∂2l​which appears in the second-order approximation of the log-likelihood l(θ)l(\theta)l(θ) near θ^\hat{\theta}θ^: l(θ)≈l(θ^)+(θ−θ^)∂l∂θ∣θ^+(θ−θ^)2∂2l∂θ2∣θ^undefined−J(θ^)l(\theta) \approx l(\hat{ \theta}) + \cancel{(\theta-\hat{\theta})\left.\frac{\partial l}{\partial \theta} \right|_{\hat{\theta}}}+(\theta-\hat{\theta})^{2} \underbrace{\left.\frac{\partial^{2} l}{\partial \theta^{2}}\right|_{\hat{\theta}}}_{-J(\hat{\theta})}l(θ)≈l(θ^)+(θ−θ^)∂θ∂l​∣∣​θ^​​+(θ−θ^)2−J(θ^)∂θ2∂2l​∣∣​θ^​​​
    • The larger J(θ^)J(\hat{ \theta})J(θ^) is, the faster log-likelihood decays when θ\thetaθ moves away from θ^\hat{\theta}θ^. In other words, large information = precise MLE.
  • The expected/Fisher information is its expectation: I(θ)=E[J]=EX[−∂2l(X,θ)∂θ2]I(\theta)=\mathbb{E}[J]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{X}}\left[ -\frac{\partial^{2} l(\mathbf{X},\theta)}{\partial \theta^{2}} \right]I(θ)=E[J]=EX​[−∂θ2∂2l(X,θ)​]In particular, the Fisher information with sample size 111 is denoted i(θ)i(\theta)i(θ). For nnn iid. samples, the identity I(θ)=n⋅i(θ)I(\theta)=n \cdot i(\theta)I(θ)=n⋅i(θ)can make algebra easier.

Properties of the MLE

  • The invariance property of MLE states that: if θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ is the MLE of θ\thetaθ, then for any function ggg, g(θ^)g(\hat{\theta})g(θ^) is the MLE of g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ).
    • That is, the MLE of the function is the function of the MLE.

Proof (when ggg injective):
Denote the likelihood as a function of θ\thetaθ as L(x,θ)L(\mathbf{x},\theta)L(x,θ), and as a function of g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ) by L∗(x,ψ)≡L(x,g−1(ψ))L^{*}(\mathbf{x},\psi)\equiv L(\mathbf{x},g^{-1}(\psi))L∗(x,ψ)≡L(x,g−1(ψ)) (ggg is invertible since it’s injective).
Then sup⁡ψL∗=sup⁡θL\sup_{\psi}L^{*}=\sup_{\theta}Lsupψ​L∗=supθ​L, and θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ maximizes RHS=L(x,θ^)\mathrm{RHS}=L(\mathbf{x},\hat{\theta})RHS=L(x,θ^).
Hence if the MLE ψ^\hat{\psi}ψ^​ maximizes LHS=L∗(x,ψ^)=L(x,g−1(ψ^))\mathrm{LHS}=L^{*}(\mathbf{x},\hat{\psi})=L(\mathbf{x},g^{-1}(\hat{\psi}))LHS=L∗(x,ψ^​)=L(x,g−1(ψ^​)), equating it with RHS\mathrm{RHS}RHS gives g−1(ψ^)=θ^g^{-1}(\hat{\psi})=\hat{\theta}g−1(ψ^​)=θ^.
Hence ψ^=g(θ^)\hat{\psi}=g(\hat{\theta})ψ^​=g(θ^) is the MLE of g(θ)g(\theta)g(θ).

  • The MLE can be numerically solved via the Newton-Raphson method, applied to the log-likelihood equation ∂l∂θ=0\frac{\partial l}{\partial \theta}=0∂θ∂l​=0.

Algorithm:
(1) start with an initial guess θ0\theta_{0}θ0​.
(2) given the previous guess θn\theta_{n}θn​, linear approximation gives ∂l∂θ∣θ^≈∂l∂θ∣θn+(θ^−θn)⋅∂2l∂θ2∣θn\left.\frac{\partial l}{\partial \theta}\right|_{\hat{\theta}} \approx \left.\frac{\partial l}{\partial \theta}\right|_{\theta_{n}}+(\hat{\theta}-\theta_{n})\cdot \left.\frac{\partial^2 l}{\partial \theta^2}\right|_{\theta_{n}}∂θ∂l​∣∣​θ^​≈∂θ∂l​∣∣​θn​​+(θ^−θn​)⋅∂θ2∂2l​∣∣​θn​​and rearranging to solve for θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ gives the new approximate θn+1\theta_{n+1}θn+1​: θ^≈θn+1≡θn+U(θn)J(θn) \hat{\theta} \approx \theta_{n+1} \equiv \theta_{n}+\frac{U(\theta_{n})}{J(\theta_{n})}θ^≈θn+1​≡θn​+J(θn​)U(θn​)​where U=∂l∂θU=\frac{\partial l}{\partial \theta}U=∂θ∂l​ is the score function and JJJ the information.
(3) repeat till sufficient convergence.

  • The asymptotic normality of the MLE θ^\hat{\theta}θ^ states that under some regularity conditions (see lecture notes), as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, (In(θ))1/2(θ^−θ)undefinedDN(0,1) (I_{n}(\theta))^{1 / 2} (\hat{\theta}-\theta)\xrightarrow{D}N(0,1)(In​(θ))1/2(θ^−θ)D​N(0,1)where InI_{n}In​ is the expected information for the MLE from nnn samples. Equivalently, for large nnn, θ^≈DN(θ,In(θ)−1)\hat{\theta} \overset{D}{\approx} N(\theta, I_{n}(\theta)^{-1})θ^≈DN(θ,In​(θ)−1)
    • Again, larger the information In=E[J]I_{n}=\mathbb{E}[J]In​=E[J], more accurate an estimate the MLE is.

The notes only provides a sketch proof, so it’s probably not examinable.

Confidence Intervals

For simplicity, the open interval centered at ccc with radius rrr is denoted as (c±r)≡(c−r,c+r)(c \pm r) \equiv (c-r, c+r)(c±r)≡(c−r,c+r)and similarly for closed and half-open intervals.

  • Recap: a 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)% confidence interval (a(X),b(X))(a(\mathbf{X}),b(\mathbf{X}))(a(X),b(X)) of some parameter θ\thetaθ is an interval such that P[θ∈(a(X),b(X))]=1−α\mathbb{P}[\theta \in \big(a(\mathbf{X}), b(\mathbf{X}))\big]=1-\alphaP[θ∈(a(X),b(X))]=1−αthat is, the interval has a (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) chance of containing θ\thetaθ.

    • Note that the interval is the random variable, not θ\thetaθ.

  • Confidence intervals are usually expected to:

    • Not depend on θ\thetaθ, otherwise we are begging the question for the value of θ\thetaθ.
    • Become tighter with more data with its expected length shrinking.

  • For example, if X1,…,Xn∼iid.N(μ,σ02)X_{1},\dots,X_{n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(\mu,\sigma_{0}^{2})X1​,…,Xn​∼iid.N(μ,σ02​) where σ0\sigma_{0}σ0​ is known, then the mean μ\muμ has a (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) confidence interval of (Xˉ±zα/2σ0n)\left( \bar{X} \pm z_{\alpha / 2}\frac{\sigma_{0}}{\sqrt{ n }} \right)(Xˉ±zα/2​n​σ0​​)where zp:1−Φ(zp)=pz_{p}:1-\Phi(z_{p})=pzp​:1−Φ(zp​)=p. It is independent of μ\muμ, and its length shrinks with larger nnn (sample size).

Asymptotic Normal CI of MLE’s

  • Because of the asymptotic normality of MLE’s, In(θ)(θ^−θ)≈DN(0,1)\sqrt{ I_{n}(\theta) }(\hat{\theta}-\theta) \overset{D}{\approx} N(0,1)In​(θ)​(θ^−θ)≈DN(0,1) when nnn is large, so P[In(θ)(θ^−θ)∈(0±zα/2)]≈1−α\mathbb{P}\left[ \sqrt{ I_{n}(\theta) }(\hat{\theta}-\theta) \in (0\pm z_{\alpha / 2}) \right] \approx 1-\alphaP[In​(θ)​(θ^−θ)∈(0±zα/2​)]≈1−αThen solving for θ\thetaθ gives its (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) CI: P[θ∈(θ^±zα/2In(θ))]≈1−α\mathbb{P}\left[\theta \in \left( \hat{\theta} \pm\frac{z_{\alpha / 2}}{\sqrt{ I_{n}(\theta) }} \right) \right] \approx 1-\alphaP[θ∈(θ^±In​(θ)​zα/2​​)]≈1−αand to make the interval independent of the true θ\thetaθ, estimate In(θ)I_{n}(\theta)In​(θ) with the expected information In(θ^)I_{n}(\hat{\theta})In​(θ^) or observed information Jn(θ^)J_{n}(\hat{\theta})Jn​(θ^) to get the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) CI: (θ^±zα/2In(θ^)) or (θ^±zα/2Jn(θ^))\left( \hat{\theta} \pm\frac{z_{\alpha / 2}}{\sqrt{ I_{n}(\hat{\theta}) }} \right) \text{ or } \left( \hat{\theta} \pm\frac{z_{\alpha / 2}}{\sqrt{ J_{n}(\hat{\theta}) }} \right)⎝⎛​θ^±In​(θ^)​zα/2​​⎠⎞​ or ⎝⎛​θ^±Jn​(θ^)​zα/2​​⎠⎞​
  • The parameter θ\thetaθ of some distributions is bounded, so estimating them with N(θ^,In(θ)−1)N(\hat{ \theta},I_{n}(\theta)^{-1})N(θ^,In​(θ)−1) defined over θ∈(−∞,∞)\theta \in(-\infty, \infty)θ∈(−∞,∞) might produce a CI that includes impossible values.
    • E.g. a CI of (0.1±0.15)(0.1 \pm 0.15)(0.1±0.15) for Ber(θ)\mathrm{Ber}(\theta)Ber(θ), but θ∈[0,1]\theta \in [0,1]θ∈[0,1] by definition.

Solution: estimate a bijective function ϕ=f(θ):[0,1]→R\phi=f(\theta):[0,1] \to \mathbb{R}ϕ=f(θ):[0,1]→R, so there are no impossible values for ϕ^\hat{\phi}ϕ^​.
First, estimate the distribution of ϕ\phiϕ. The delta method gives ϕ^≈DN(ϕ,f′(θ)2In(θ))\hat{\phi} \overset{D}{\approx}N\left(\phi, \frac{f'(\theta)^2}{I_{n}(\theta)} \right)ϕ^​≈DN(ϕ,In​(θ)f′(θ)2​)
Second, compute the CI with standard methods, giving say (ϕ1,ϕ2)(\phi_{1}, \phi_{2})(ϕ1​,ϕ2​).
Lastly, transform back to θ\thetaθ: since MLE’s are invariant, θ^=f−1(ϕ^)\hat{ \theta}=f^{-1}(\hat{\phi})θ^=f−1(ϕ^​), and the CI is (f−1(ϕ1),f−1(ϕ2))(f^{-1}(\phi_{1}),f^{-1}(\phi_{2}))(f−1(ϕ1​),f−1(ϕ2​)).

The Chi-Squared Distribution

Big idea: chi-squared is the sum of iid. Gaussians squared. It can construct a CI for the variance of N(0,σ2)N(0,\sigma^{2})N(0,σ2).

  • How can we estimate the variance σ2\sigma^{2}σ2 in N(0,σ2)N(0, \sigma^{2})N(0,σ2) from iid. samples X1,…,nX_{1, \dots, n}X1,…,n​ with a CI?

  • The initial guess is to derive something from ∑iXinσ∼N(0,1n)\frac{\sum_{i}X_{i}}{n\sigma}\sim N\left( 0, \frac{1}{n} \right)nσ∑i​Xi​​∼N(0,n1​), but adding more samples does not improve this CI.

  • The chi-squared distribution with nnn degrees of freedom is denoted χn2\chi_{n}^{2}χn2​, and it is the sum of the square of iid. standard normals: if X1,…,n∼iid.N(0,1)X_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(0,1)X1,…,n​∼iid.N(0,1), ∑i=1nXi2∼χn2\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i}^{2} \sim \chi_{n}^2i=1∑n​Xi2​∼χn2​and their pdf.'s under kkk degrees of freedom are:

  • Confidence interval with χ2\chi^{2}χ2 distribution: standardizing X1,…,n∼iid.N(0,σ2)X_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(0,\sigma^{2})X1,…,n​∼iid.N(0,σ2) gives ∑iXi2σ2∼χn2\frac{\sum_{i}X_{i}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}} \sim \chi_{n}^{2}σ2∑i​Xi2​​∼χn2​ and the variance σ2\sigma^2σ2 has the CI: P[∑iXi2σ2∈(c1,c2)]=P[σ2∈(∑iXi2c1,∑iXi2c2)]= 1−α \mathbb{P}\left[ \frac{\sum_{i}X_{i}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}} \in (c_{1},c_{2}) \right]=\mathbb{P}\left[ \sigma^{2} \in \left( \frac{\sum_{i}X^{2}_{i}}{c_{1}},\frac{\sum_{i}X^{2}_{i}}{c_{2}}\right) \right] =\,1-\alphaP[σ2∑i​Xi2​​∈(c1​,c2​)]=P[σ2∈(c1​∑i​Xi2​​,c2​∑i​Xi2​​)]=1−αby setting c1,2c_{1,2}c1,2​ as appropriate percentiles of χn2\chi_{n}^{2}χn2​.

  • As nnn increases, the distribution of χn2\chi_{n}^{2}χn2​ flattens faster (i.e. c1,2c_{1,2}c1,2​ grows faster) than the increase in ∑iXi2\sum_{i}X^{2}_{i}∑i​Xi2​, so the (expected) CI length improves with more samples:

Chisq_CI_length <- function(n,alpha=0.01){
  lower = n / qchisq(1-alpha, df=n)
  upper = n / qchisq(alpha, df=n)
  return(upper-lower)
}
CI_lengths <- sapply(10:100, Chisq_CI_length)
plot(10:100, CI_lengths, xlab="n", ylab="CI length")

The t-Distribution

Big idea: the t-distribution is a bell-shaped distribution with a heavier tail than the normal. The t-statistic follows the t-distribution.

  • To estimate the mean of N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^{2})N(μ,σ2) with known variance, normalizing the sample mean with σ\sigmaσ gives the z-statistic: Z=Xˉ−μσ/nZ=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\sigma / \sqrt{ n }}Z=σ/n​Xˉ−μ​

  • But if σ2\sigma^{2}σ2 is unknown, we need a statistic involving μ\muμ but not σ2\sigma^{2}σ2 to derive a confidence interval of μ\muμ: normalizing with the sample variance SSS instead of σ\sigmaσ gives the t-statistic: T=Xˉ−μS/n, where S2=∑i(Xi−Xˉ)2n−1T=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu }{S / \sqrt{ n }} , \text{ where }S^{2}=\frac{\sum_{i}(X_{i}-\bar{X})^2}{n-1}T=S/n​Xˉ−μ​, where S2=n−1∑i​(Xi​−Xˉ)2​Note that S2S^{2}S2 looks proportional to some χ2\chi^{2}χ2 distribution, and (Xˉ−μ)∼N(0,σ2n)(\bar{X}-\mu) \sim N\left(0,\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n} \right)(Xˉ−μ)∼N(0,nσ2​). What’s the distribution of their ratio?

  • Independent random variables Z∼N(0,1)Z \sim N(0,1)Z∼N(0,1) and Y∼χr2Y \sim \chi^{2}_{r}Y∼χr2​ produce the (Student) t-distribution with rrr degrees of freedom: ZY/r∼tr\frac{Z}{\sqrt{ Y / r }} \sim t_{r}Y/r​Z​∼tr​and we will see that the t-statistic has the t-distribution. Their pdf’s under ν\nuν degrees of freedom are:

  • As the degree of freedom n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, tnundefinedDN(0,1)t_{n} \xrightarrow{D} N(0,1)tn​D​N(0,1).

    • that is, the t-distribution is asymptotically normal.

Sketch proof: as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞, by law of large numbers, if Yn∼χn2Y_{n} \sim \chi^{2}_{n}Yn​∼χn2​, Ynn=1n∑i=1nXi2undefinedPE[Xi2]=Var(Xi)−E[Xi]2=1\frac{Y_{n}}{n} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i}^{2} \xrightarrow{P} \mathbb{E}[X_{i}^{2}]=\mathrm{Var}(X_{i})-\mathbb{E}[X_{i}]^{2}=1nYn​​=n1​i=1∑n​Xi2​P​E[Xi2​]=Var(Xi​)−E[Xi​]2=1Hence tn∼ZYn/n≈DZ∼N(0,1)t_{n} \sim \frac{Z}{\sqrt{ Y_{n} / n }} \overset{D}{\approx} Z \sim N(0,1)tn​∼Yn​/n​Z​≈DZ∼N(0,1).

  • The t-statistic of nnn samples follows the t-distribution tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​:
    • The sample variance S2S^{2}S2 and mean Xˉ\bar{X}Xˉ are independent,
    • Their distributions are n−1σ2S2∼χn−12\frac{n-1}{\sigma^{2}}S^{2} \sim \chi^{2}_{n-1}σ2n−1​S2∼χn−12​, Xˉ∼N(μ,σ2/n)\bar{X} \sim N(\mu,\sigma^{2} / n)Xˉ∼N(μ,σ2/n),
    • Hence the t-statistic follows the t-distribution: T=Xˉ−μS/n∼tn−1T=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{S / \sqrt{ n }} \sim t_{n-1}T=S/n​Xˉ−μ​∼tn−1​

Proof: WLOG assume the samples are Z1,…,n∼iid.N(0,1)Z_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(0,1)Z1,…,n​∼iid.N(0,1), since if Zi=Xi−μσZ_{i}=\frac{X_{i}-\mu}{\sigma}Zi​=σXi​−μ​ have independent mean and variances, so do X1,…,nX_{1,\dots,n}X1,…,n​.

Now linearly map Z1,…,nZ_{1,\dots,n}Z1,…,n​ to Y1,…,n∼iid.N(0,1)Y_{1,\dots ,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(0,1)Y1,…,n​∼iid.N(0,1) so that: (1) Y1=nZˉY_1=\sqrt{ n }\bar{Z}Y1​=n​Zˉ records the sample mean, and (2) the sample variance SZ2S^{2}_{Z}SZ2​ is only dependent on Y2,…,nY_{2,\dots,n}Y2,…,n​ (hence independent of the mean).

This transformation is done by Y=AZ\mathbf{Y}=A\mathbf{Z}Y=AZ, where (1) the first row of AAA is a1=(1n,…,1n)\mathbf{a}_{1}=\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{ n }},\dots, \frac{1}{\sqrt{ n }} \right)a1​=(n​1​,…,n​1​)so that Y1=Zˉ⋅nY_{1}=\bar{Z} \cdot \sqrt{ n }Y1​=Zˉ⋅n​, and (2) AAA is orthogonal, so that Y1,…,n∼iid.N(0,1)Y_{1,\dots ,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(0,1)Y1,…,n​∼iid.N(0,1), as their covariance matrix is ATA=IA^{T}A=IATA=I (which is equivalent to independence for multivariate Gaussians).

This is possible by first taking a1\mathbf{a}_{1}a1​ as required, and filling the other rows by extending a1\mathbf{a}_{1}a1​ to an orthonormal basis of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn.

Then the sample variance is only dependent on Y2,…,nY_{2,\dots,n}Y2,…,n​: (n−1)SZ2=∑i(Zi−Zˉ)2=∑iZi2−nZˉ2=∑iYi2−Y12=∑i≥2Yi2\begin{align*} (n-1)S_{Z}^{2}&=\sum_{i}(Z_{i}-\bar{Z})^{2}\\ &= \sum_{i}Z_{i}^{2}-n\bar{Z}^{2}\\ &= \sum_{i}Y_{i}^{2}-Y_{1}^{2} \\ &= \sum_{i \ge 2} Y_{i}^{2} \end{align*}(n−1)SZ2​​=i∑​(Zi​−Zˉ)2=i∑​Zi2​−nZˉ2=i∑​Yi2​−Y12​=i≥2∑​Yi2​​Where ∑iYi2=YTY=ZTATAZ=ZTZ=∑iZ2\sum_{i}Y_{i}^{2}=\mathbf{Y}^{T}\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{Z}^{T}A^{T}A\mathbf{Z}=\mathbf{Z}^{T}\mathbf{Z}=\sum_{i}Z^{2}∑i​Yi2​=YTY=ZTATAZ=ZTZ=∑i​Z2.

Hence Zˉ=Y1/n\bar{Z}=Y_{1} / \sqrt{ n }Zˉ=Y1​/n​ and SZ2=∑i≥2Yi2∼χn−12S_{Z}^{2}=\sum_{i \ge 2}Y_{i}^{2} \sim \chi^{2}_{n-1}SZ2​=∑i≥2​Yi2​∼χn−12​ are independent. Then the t-statistic follows the t-distribution by definition.

  • Confidence interval with t-distribution: the t-statistic TTT of X1,…,n∼iid.N(μ,σ2)X_{1,\dots,n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} N(\mu,\sigma^{2})X1,…,n​∼iid.N(μ,σ2) has tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​ distribution, so: P[T=Xˉ−μS/n∈(0±τα)]=P[μ∈(Xˉ±Snτα)]=1−α\mathbb{P}\left[ T=\frac{\bar{X}-\mu }{S / \sqrt{ n }} \in (0\pm\tau_{\alpha}) \right]=\mathbb{P}\left[ \mu \in \left( \bar{X}\pm\frac{S}{\sqrt{ n }}\tau_{\alpha} \right) \right]=1-\alphaP[T=S/n​Xˉ−μ​∈(0±τα​)]=P[μ∈(Xˉ±n​S​τα​)]=1−αgives the (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) CI of the mean μ\muμ, which is independent of θ\thetaθ. Here τα\tau_{\alpha}τα​ is the upper α\alphaα percentile of the t-distribution.

Hypothesis Testing: Theory

  • Suppose we want to study a random variable X\mathbf{X}X to determine its distribution, using the observed values x\mathbf{x}x.
  • For now, the distribution is assumed to be a family f(X;θ)f(\mathbf{X};\theta)f(X;θ), where θ\thetaθ is the parameter yet to be determined/tested. Later, we will test for different things, e.g. if the family is appropriate for modeling the data.

Definitions

  • In a hypothesis test, the null hypothesis H0H_{0}H0​ is the statement assumed to be true, and we check if the evidence disagrees with it.
  • For parameter testing, the most common null hypotheses is the simple null hypothesis: that θ=θ0\theta=\theta_{0}θ=θ0​.
  • The alternative hypothesis H1H_{1}H1​ (or HaH_{a}Ha​) is the statement we will embrace, if evidence disagrees with H0H_{0}H0​.
  • For a parameter θ\thetaθ and a null hypothesis H0:θ=θ0H_{0}:\theta=\theta_{0}H0​:θ=θ0​, common alternative hypothesis include:
    • A simple alternative hypothesis: that θ=θ1≠θ0\theta=\theta_{1} \ne \theta_{0}θ=θ1​=θ0​.
    • A one-sided alternative hypothesis: that θ>θ0\theta > \theta_{0}θ>θ0​ (or θ<θ0\theta < \theta_{0}θ<θ0​).
    • A two-sided alternative hypothesis: that θ≠θ0\theta \ne \theta_{0}θ=θ0​.
  • Given data X=x\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{x}X=x, the test statistic is a function t(X)t(\mathbf{X})t(X), ideally unlikely to take extreme values if H0H_{0}H0​ is true. Its observed value is denoted tobs=t(x)t_{\mathrm{obs}}=t(\mathbf{x})tobs​=t(x).
    • Hence an extreme value of tobst_{\text{obs}}tobs​ suggests that H0H_{0}H0​ is incorrect.

Rejecting the Null Hypothesis

  • In order to reject the null hypothesis, some criterion is needed: the p-value gives the most common and basic criterion.
  • The p-value (of the statistic ttt) is the probability of getting a t(X)t(\mathbf{X})t(X) at least as extreme as tobst_{\mathrm{obs}}tobs​, assuming H0H_{0}H0​ to be true: p≡P(getting t(X) as extreme as tobs ∣ H0)p\equiv \mathbb{P}(\text{getting }t(\mathbf{X}) \text{ as extreme as }t_{\mathrm{obs}}\,|\, H_{0})p≡P(getting t(X) as extreme as tobs​∣H0​)And the criterion for rejecting the null hypothesis is whether the p-value is smaller than some threshold, which suggests that the data disagrees with the null hypothesis.
  • Different alternative hypothesis consider different values of ttt to be “extreme”:
    • One-sided hypotheses H1:(θ>θ0)H_{1}: (\theta > \theta_{0})H1​:(θ>θ0​) only count values of ttt corresponding to large θ\thetaθ (similarly for H1:(θ<θ0)H_{1}:(\theta<\theta_{0})H1​:(θ<θ0​)).
    • Two-sided hypotheses H1:(θ≠θ0)H_{1}:(\theta \ne \theta_{0})H1​:(θ=θ0​) count ttt corresponding to θ\thetaθ far from θ0\theta_{0}θ0​ (in either direction) as extreme.
    • For most choices of ttt, large θ\thetaθ = large ttt, so the p-values are:
      One-sided:p=P(t(X)≥tobs ∣ H0)Two-sided:p=P(∣t(X)∣≥∣tobs∣ ∣ H0)\begin{align*} \text{One-sided}: p &=\mathbb{P}\big(t(\mathbf{X}) \ge t_{\mathrm{obs}} \,|\, H_{0}\big)\\ \text{Two-sided}: p &= \mathbb{P}\big(|t(\mathbf{X})| \ge |t_{\mathrm{obs}}| \,|\, H_{0}\big) \end{align*}One-sided:pTwo-sided:p​=P(t(X)≥tobs​∣H0​)=P(∣t(X)∣≥∣tobs​∣∣H0​)​
  • More generally, given some criterion to reject H0H_{0}H0​, the critical region C⊆RnC \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}C⊆Rn is the region containing the samples that would lead to the rejection of H0H_{0}H0​: C≡{x∈Rn ∣ H0 rejected given X=x}C \equiv \{ \mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \,|\, H_{0} \text{ rejected given } \mathbf{X}=\mathbf{ x} \}C≡{x∈Rn∣H0​ rejected given X=x}in the case of using p-values, C={x∈Rn ∣ p(x)<threshold}C=\{ \mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \,|\, p(\mathbf{x}) < \text{threshold}\}C={x∈Rn∣p(x)<threshold}

Errors in Hypothesis Testing

  • A type I error is a false positive: rejecting H0H_{0}H0​ when it is true.
  • A type II error is a false negative: failing to reject H0H_{0}H0​ when it is false.
  • Given simple hypotheses H0:θ=θ0H_{0}:\theta=\theta_{0}H0​:θ=θ0​ and H1:θ=θ1H_{1}:\theta=\theta_{1}H1​:θ=θ1​,
    • the size of the test is the probability of type I error: α≡P(X∈C ∣ H0)\alpha \equiv\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{X} \in C\,|\, H_{0})α≡P(X∈C∣H0​);
    • the probability of type II error is denoted β=P(X∉C ∣ H1)\beta=\mathbb{P}( \mathbf{X} \notin C \,|\, H_{1})β=P(X∈/C∣H1​);
    • the power of the test is 1−β1-\beta1−β, i.e. the probability of rejecting H0H_{0}H0​ when H1H_{1}H1​ is true.
  • Given composite hypotheses H0:θ∈Θ0H_{0}:\theta \in \Theta_{0}H0​:θ∈Θ0​ and H1:θ∈Θ1H_{1}:\theta \in \Theta_{1}H1​:θ∈Θ1​,
    • the size is α≡sup⁡θ∈Θ0P(X∈C ∣ θ)\alpha \equiv \sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{0}}\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{X} \in C \,|\, \theta)α≡supθ∈Θ0​​P(X∈C∣θ),
    • the power is now a function w(θ)=P(X∈C ∣ θ)w(\theta)=\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{X} \in C \,|\, \theta)w(θ)=P(X∈C∣θ).

Connection to Confidence Intervals

  • Suppose we are testing the simple hypotheses H0:θ=θ0H_{0}:\theta=\theta_{0}H0​:θ=θ0​ against H1:θ≠θ0H_{1}:\theta \ne \theta_{0}H1​:θ=θ0​, and we have data X∼F(θ)\mathbf{X} \sim F(\theta)X∼F(θ).
  • Let (a(x),b(x))\big(a(\mathbf{x}),b(\mathbf{x})\big)(a(x),b(x)) be the (1−α)%(1-\alpha)\%(1−α)% CI for θ\thetaθ derived from the data, then p(x)<α  ⟺  θ0∉(a(x),b(x))p(\mathbf{x})<\alpha \iff \theta_{0} \not \in \big(a(\mathbf{x}),b(\mathbf{x})\big)p(x)<α⟺θ0​∈(a(x),b(x))and if we set α\alphaα as the threshold of p-value for rejecting H0H_{0}H0​, reject H0  ⟺  θ0∉(a(x),b(x))\text{reject }H_{0} \iff \theta_{0} \not \in \big(a(\mathbf{x}),b(\mathbf{x})\big)reject H0​⟺θ0​∈(a(x),b(x))

Testing with Likelihood Ratios

Big idea: instead of p-values, we can use the likelihood ratio for testing.

  • Consider a test of H0H_{0}H0​ against H1H_{1}H1​ with some data X=x\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{x}X=x.
  • The likelihood ratio (of H0H_{0}H0​ to H1H_{1}H1​) is something that looks like λ(x)=L(x ∣ H0)L(x ∣ H1)\lambda(\mathbf{x})=\frac{L(\mathbf{x}\,|\,H_{0})}{L(\mathbf{x}\,|\,H_{1})}λ(x)=L(x∣H1​)L(x∣H0​)​
  • Data that are consistent with H0H_{0}H0​ have large ratios, and small ratios mean disagreement; hence we can use the likelihood as a criterion for rejection, giving:
  • The likelihood ratio test (LRT) is any test with critical region of the form C={x: λ(x)≤k}C=\{ \mathbf{x}:\, \lambda(\mathbf{x}) \le k \}C={x:λ(x)≤k}

The Neyman-Pearson Lemma

Big idea: Using the likelihood ratio as the criterion to reject H0H_{0}H0​ produces the best test.

  • For simple hypotheses H0:θ=θ0H_{0}: \theta=\theta_{0}H0​:θ=θ0​ and H1:θ=θ1H_{1}:\theta=\theta_{1}H1​:θ=θ1​. Here the likelihood ratio is λ(x)=L(x;θ0)L(x;θ1)\lambda(\mathbf{x})=\frac{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1})}λ(x)=L(x;θ1​)L(x;θ0​)​
  • Neyman-Pearson Lemma: given these simple hypotheses and α>0\alpha >0α>0, the LRT is the most powerful test that has size ≤α\le \alpha≤α.
  • More precisely, among all tests with size ≤α\le\alpha≤α, the one with the largest power has critical region C={x:L(x;θ0)L(x;θ1)≤kα}C=\left\{ \mathbf{x}: \frac{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1})} \le k_{\alpha} \right\}C={x:L(x;θ1​)L(x;θ0​)​≤kα​}where kαk_{\alpha}kα​ is chosen so that the test has size α\alphaα.
    • That is, if the criterion is to reject H0H_{0}H0​ when λ\lambdaλ is too small, it produces the most powerful test.

Proof: for any test with size ≤α\le\alpha≤α and critical region AAA, we shall prove that it has less (or equal) power. Consider the function F≡(1C−1A){L(x;θ1)−1kL(x;θ0)}F \equiv (\Bbb{1}_{C}-\Bbb{1}_{A})\left\{ L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1})-\frac{1}{k}L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0}) \right\}F≡(1C​−1A​){L(x;θ1​)−k1​L(x;θ0​)}which is non-negative (both factors are non-negative when x∈C\mathbf{x} \in Cx∈C, and both non-positive otherwise).
Then its integral is also non-negative, and noting that ∫RL(x;θ)=P(x∈R ∣ θ)\int _{R} L(\mathbf{x};\theta)=\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x} \in R \,|\,\theta)∫R​L(x;θ)=P(x∈R∣θ), expand the parentheses to get: 0≤∫RnF=∫C{… }−∫A{… }=∫CL(x;θ1)undefinedpower(C)−1k∫CL(x;θ0)undefinedsize(C)=α−∫AL(x;θ1)undefinedpower(A)+1k∫AL(x;θ0)undefinedsize(A)≤α≤power(C)−power(A)\begin{align*} 0 \le\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} F &= \int _{C} \{\dots\} - \int _{A} \{\dots\} \\ &= \underbrace{\int_{C} L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1}) }_{\text{power}(C)} - \frac{1}{k} \underbrace{ \int _{C} L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}_{\text{size}(C)=\alpha}- \underbrace{\int_{A} L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1}) }_{\text{power}(A)} + \frac{1}{k} \underbrace{ \int _{A} L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}_{\text{size}(A) \le \alpha}\\ &\le \text{power}(C)-\text{power}(A) \end{align*}0≤∫Rn​F​=∫C​{…}−∫A​{…}=power(C)∫C​L(x;θ1​)​​−k1​size(C)=α∫C​L(x;θ0​)​​−power(A)∫A​L(x;θ1​)​​+k1​size(A)≤α∫A​L(x;θ0​)​​≤power(C)−power(A)​hence power(C)≥power(A)\text{power}(C) \ge \text{power}(A)power(C)≥power(A).

  • This does not mean that p-values are bad – likelihood ratios and p-values are sometimes just different ways to derive the same critical region.
    • For example, suppose the test is on X∼N(μ,σ2)\mathbf{X} \sim N(\mu,\sigma^{2})X∼N(μ,σ2) with unknown variance and mean.
    • The hypotheses are H0:μ=0H_{0}:\mu=0H0​:μ=0 and H1:μ>0H_{1}:\mu>{0}H1​:μ>0.
    • Then both the likelihood ratio criterion and the p-value of a t-test lead to the critical region {x:xˉ≥cα}\{ \mathbf{x}:\bar{\mathbf{x}} \ge c_{\alpha} \}{x:xˉ≥cα​} for some constant cαc_{\alpha}cα​.

Uniformly Most Powerful Tests

  • Suppose instead of testing H0:θ=θ0H_{0}:\theta=\theta_{0}H0​:θ=θ0​ against the simple alternative H1=θ1H_{1}=\theta_{1}H1​=θ1​, the alternative is H1:θ∈Θ1H_{1}:\theta \in \Theta_{1}H1​:θ∈Θ1​. Then the likelihood ratio is a function over Θ1\Theta_{1}Θ1​: λ(x,θ1)=L(x;θ0)L(x;θ1)\lambda(\mathbf{x},\theta_{1})=\frac{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1})}λ(x,θ1​)=L(x;θ1​)L(x;θ0​)​
  • The critical region of the LRT is then also a function of θ1∈Θ1\theta_{1} \in \Theta_{1}θ1​∈Θ1​: C(θ1)={x:L(x;θ0)L(x;θ1)≤kα}C(\theta_{1})=\left\{ \mathbf{x}: \frac{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0})}{L(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1})} \le k_{\alpha} \right\}C(θ1​)={x:L(x;θ1​)L(x;θ0​)​≤kα​}
  • If the CCC defined above is independent of θ1∈Θ1\theta_{1} \in \Theta_{1}θ1​∈Θ1​, then it is uniformly most powerful (UMP).
  • For example, in testing a normal sample for H0:μ=0H_{0}:\mu=0H0​:μ=0 against H1:μ>0H_{1}: \mu >0H1​:μ>0, the critical region with size α\alphaα is the same, hence the critical region {x:xˉ≥cα}\{ \mathbf{x}:\bar{\mathbf{x}} \ge c_{\alpha} \}{x:xˉ≥cα​} is UMP.
  • Usually, UMP critical regions only appear in one-sided tests, where all alternatives favor data that deviates in the same direction.

Generalized Likelihood Ratio Tests

Big idea: likelihood ratio tests can determine whether a simpler model is good enough for the data.

  • Consider a hypothesis test of two composite hypotheses: H0: θ∈Θ0H1: θ∈Θ1⊃Θ0\begin{align*} H_{0}:\, &\theta \in \Theta_{0}\\ H_{1}:\, &\theta \in \Theta_{1} \supset \Theta_{0} \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​θ∈Θ0​θ∈Θ1​⊃Θ0​​Hence H0H_{0}H0​ is a simplification of H1H_{1}H1​, in the sense that θ\thetaθ has fewer possible values.
  • The null hypothesis is nested within the alternative, and the test decides if simplifying H1H_{1}H1​ to H0H_{0}H0​ is reasonable.
    • We accept H0H_{0}H0​ if the simpler H0H_{0}H0​ explains the data reasonably well, corresponding to a large likelihood ratio.
    • For example, for H0:N(0,σ2)H_{0}:N(0,\sigma^{2})H0​:N(0,σ2) and H1:N(μ,σ2)H_{1}:N(\mu,\sigma^{2})H1​:N(μ,σ2), the parameter spaces are Θ0={0}×R≥0\Theta_{0}=\{ 0 \} \times \mathbb{R}^{\ge 0}Θ0​={0}×R≥0 and Θ1=R×R≥0\Theta_{1}=\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{\ge 0}Θ1​=R×R≥0.
  • For such a test, the likelihood ratio is defined to be λ(x)=sup⁡θ∈Θ0L(θ,x)sup⁡θ∈Θ1L(θ,x)\lambda(\mathbf{x})=\frac{\sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{0}}L(\theta,\mathbf{x})}{\sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{1}}L(\theta,\mathbf{x})}λ(x)=supθ∈Θ1​​L(θ,x)supθ∈Θ0​​L(θ,x)​which is just plugging in the MLE of θ\thetaθ in Θ0\Theta_{0}Θ0​ and Θ1\Theta_{1}Θ1​ into the likelihoods; these MLE’s could be different, since Θ1\Theta_{1}Θ1​ is larger.
  • The (generalized) likelihood ratio test has corresponding critical region is Cα={x:λ(x)≤kα}C_{\alpha}=\{ \mathbf{x} : \lambda(\mathbf{x}) \le k_{\alpha} \}Cα​={x:λ(x)≤kα​}for some kαk_{\alpha}kα​ chosen so that the size of the test is α\alphaα: size=sup⁡θ∈Θ0P(λ(X)≤kα ∣ θ)=α\text{size}=\sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{0}}\mathbb{P}(\lambda(\mathbf{X})\le k_{\alpha}\,|\,\theta)=\alphasize=θ∈Θ0​sup​P(λ(X)≤kα​∣θ)=α
  • To actually get a test, we need to find such a kαk_{\alpha}kα​ by:
    • (1) directly computing it, if we can simplify the condition λ(X)≤kα\lambda(\mathbf{X}) \le k_{\alpha}λ(X)≤kα​ to some equivalent condition involving X\mathbf{X}X only. This is only possible for a few distributions of X\mathbf{X}X, e.g N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^{2})N(μ,σ2) in example 3.93.93.9 in the notes.
    • (2) approximating the distribution of Λ=−2log⁡(λ(X))≈Dχ2\Lambda=-2\log(\lambda(\mathbf{X})) \overset{D}{\approx}\chi^{2}Λ=−2log(λ(X))≈Dχ2, see the following section.

The Likelihood Ratio Statistic

Big idea: the log-of-ratio-of-likelihoods is asymptotically χ2\chi^{2}χ2.

  • Confusingly, the likelihood ratio statistic is essentially the logarithm of the likelihood ratio: Λ(X)≡−2log⁡λ(X)=−2(log⁡[sup⁡θ∈Θ0L(θ,x)]−log⁡[sup⁡θ∈Θ1L(θ,x)])\Lambda(\mathbf{X}) \equiv -2\log \lambda(\mathbf{X})=-2\left(\log\left[\sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{0}}L(\theta,\mathbf{x})\right]-\log\left[\sup_{\theta \in \Theta_{1}}L(\theta,\mathbf{x})\right]\right)Λ(X)≡−2logλ(X)=−2(log[θ∈Θ0​sup​L(θ,x)]−log[θ∈Θ1​sup​L(θ,x)])
  • Wilk’s Theorem: when we assume H0H_{0}H0​ to be true, along with a few other conditions, Λ(X)=−2log⁡(λ(X))≈Dχp2\Lambda(\mathbf{X})=-2\log(\lambda(\mathbf{X})) \overset{D}{\approx}\chi^{2}_{p}Λ(X)=−2log(λ(X))≈Dχp2​where p=dim⁡Θ1−dim⁡Θ0p=\dim\Theta_{1}-\dim\Theta_{0}p=dimΘ1​−dimΘ0​.
    • The dimensions are the number of parameters that can be chosen freely, e.g. 2 in N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^{2})N(μ,σ2).

The proof is just a sketch proof of the simplest case, so probably not examinable.

  • Then asymptotically, the critical region of the generalized LRT is C≈{x: Λ(x)≥lα}C \approx \{ \mathbf{x}:\, \Lambda(\mathbf{x}) \ge l_{\alpha} \}C≈{x:Λ(x)≥lα​}where lαl_{\alpha}lα​ is the upper α\alphaα-percentile of χp2\chi_{p}^{2}χp2​.

Testing Goodness of Fit

  • Consider a sample of nnn observations, each could independently belong to one of the categories 1∼k1 \sim k1∼k.
  • The observed count of category iii is denoted OiO_{i}Oi​ or nin_{i}ni​.
  • A certain model would predict the expected count of category iii, which is denoted EiE_{i}Ei​.
  • The goodness of fit refers to how well the model’s expectations match the observed data.
  • In this case, H0H_{0}H0​ is that the model is sufficient, and H1H_{1}H1​ is usually that some more complex model is required (so H0⊆H1H_{0} \subseteq H_{1}H0​⊆H1​). Most commonly, H0: {M ∣ M∈the family of models}H1: {M ∣ M is any model}\begin{align*} H_{0}: \,&\{ M\,|\, M \in \text{the family of models} \}\\ H_{1}: \,&\{ M\,|\, M \text{ is any model} \} \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​{M∣M∈the family of models}{M∣M is any model}​where “any model” means the bare minimum of consistency, that the probabilities assigned to the categories add up to exactly 111.

The Multinomial Distribution

  • A population following a multinomial distribution has the probabilities π=(π1,…,πk)\pi=(\pi_{1},\dots,\pi_{k})π=(π1​,…,πk​), where πi=P(X is in category i)\pi_{i}=\mathbb{P}(X \text{ is in category } i)πi​=P(X is in category i) for some random sample XXX from the population.
    • Hence ∑iπi=1\sum_{i}\pi_{i}=1∑i​πi​=1.
  • For a multinomial distribution and an iid. sample X=(X1,…,Xn)\mathbf{X}=(X_{1},\dots,X_{n})X=(X1​,…,Xn​) that has observed counts n1,…,nkn_{1},\dots,n_{k}n1​,…,nk​, its likelihood is L(X;π)=n!n1!⋯nk!∏i=1kπiniL(\mathbf{X};\pi)=\frac{n!}{n_{1}!\cdots n_{k}!}\prod^{k}_{i=1}\pi_{i}^{n_{i}}L(X;π)=n1​!⋯nk​!n!​i=1∏k​πini​​
  • As seen in the lectures, if no assumptions are made about π\piπ (other than that ∑iπi=1\sum_{i} \pi_{i}=1∑i​πi​=1), the MLE is πi^=nin=proportion of category i in the sample\hat{\pi_{i}}=\frac{n_{i}}{n}=\text{proportion of category $i$ in the sample}πi​^​=nni​​=proportion of category i in the samplein other words, this is the MLE over the space of “anything that makes sense”.

LRT on Models of Multinomials

Big idea: models of multinomials can be tested with the likelihood ratio statistic, and accepted/rejected based on the p-value.

  • The MLE above allows any π\piπ, as long as it sums to 1; models might impose further restrictions on π\piπ, say dependence on a parameter θ\thetaθ: e.g. the three categories in Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium are modeled by π(θ)=((1−θ)2, 2θ(1−θ), θ2)\pi(\theta)=\left( (1-\theta)^{2},\,2\theta(1-\theta),\,\theta^{2}\right)π(θ)=((1−θ)2,2θ(1−θ),θ2)In this case the MLE is denoted π(θ^)\pi(\hat{\theta})π(θ^), a single-variable optimization on θ\thetaθ.
  • Suppose we want to test a model π(θ)\pi(\theta)π(θ) on the multinomial data, a simplification to the hypothesis of “anything that makes sense”. This sounds like a LRT on: H0:π=π(θ)H1:π can be anything as long as ∑iπi=1\begin{align*} &H_{0}:\pi=\pi(\theta)\\ &H_{1}: \pi \text{ can be anything as long as } \sum_{i}\pi_{i}=1 \end{align*}​H0​:π=π(θ)H1​:π can be anything as long as i∑​πi​=1​
  • The likelihood ratio statistic is then Λ=−2log⁡(sup⁡H0Lsup⁡H1L)=−2log⁡(L(π(θ^))L(π^))=…(see notes)=2∑inilog⁡(ninπi(θ^))=2∑iOilog⁡(OiEi)\begin{align*} \Lambda&= -2\log\left( \frac{\sup_{H_{0}}L}{\sup_{H_{1}}L} \right)\\ &= -2 \log\left( \frac{L(\pi(\hat{\theta}))}{L(\hat{\pi})} \right)\\ &= \overset{(\text{see notes})}{\dots}\\ &= 2\sum_{i}n_{i}\log\left( \frac{n_{i}}{n\pi_{i}(\hat{\theta})} \right)\\ &= 2\sum_{i}O_{i}\log\left( \frac{O_{i}}{E_{i}} \right) \end{align*}Λ​=−2log(supH1​​LsupH0​​L​)=−2log(L(π^)L(π(θ^))​)=…(see notes)=2i∑​ni​log(nπi​(θ^)ni​​)=2i∑​Oi​log(Ei​Oi​​)​
  • The asymptotic distribution of Λ\LambdaΛ is χk−1−q2\chi^{2}_{k-1-q}χk−1−q2​, where kkk is the number of categories, qqq the number of parameters in the model (e.g. 1 in Hardy-Weinberg).
    • dim⁡(Θ0)=q\dim(\Theta_{0})=qdim(Θ0​)=q by definition.
    • dim⁡(Θ1)=k−1\dim(\Theta_{1})=k-1dim(Θ1​)=k−1 because we can freely choose the first k−1k-1k−1 terms in π\piπ, but πk=1−∑i=1k−1πi\pi_{k}=1-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1} \pi_{i}πk​=1−∑i=1k−1​πi​ is determined.
  • Using Λ\LambdaΛ as the statistic, we can then test the hypotheses H0H_{0}H0​ and H1H_{1}H1​ by the p-value computed from its distribution:Λ=2∑iOilog⁡(OiEi)∼χk−1−q2  (assuming H0 is true)p=P(Λ≥Λobs ∣ H0) \begin{align*} \Lambda&= 2\sum_{i}O_{i}\log\left( \frac{O_{i}}{E_{i}} \right) \sim \chi^{2}_{k-1-q} \,\,(\text{assuming $H_{0}$ is true})\\ p &= \mathbb{P}(\Lambda \ge \Lambda_{\text{obs}} \,|\, H_{0}) \end{align*} Λp​=2i∑​Oi​log(Ei​Oi​​)∼χk−1−q2​(assuming H0​ is true)=P(Λ≥Λobs​∣H0​)​where Λobs\Lambda_{\text{obs}}Λobs​ is the observed value.

Pearson’s Chi-Squared Test

  • Suppose we don’t want to compute the logarithm in the likelihood ratio statistic, because we are lazy, or we don’t have computers.
  • Taylor expansion on Oilog⁡(Oi/Ei)O_{i}\log(O_{i} / E_{i})Oi​log(Oi​/Ei​) around EiE_{i}Ei​ gives Oilog⁡(OiEi)≈(Oi−Ei)+(Oi−Ei)22EiO_{i}\log\left( \frac{O_{i}}{E_{i}} \right) \approx (O_{i}-E_{i})+\frac{(O_{i}-E_{i})^{2}}{2E_{i}}Oi​log(Ei​Oi​​)≈(Oi​−Ei​)+2Ei​(Oi​−Ei​)2​hence substituting it into the likelihood ratio statistic gives Λ≈∑i(Oi−Ei)2Ei\Lambda \approx \sum_{i} \frac{(O_{i}-E_{i})^{2}}{E_{i}}Λ≈i∑​Ei​(Oi​−Ei​)2​where the linear terms sum to 000 since ∑iOi=∑iEi=n\sum_{i}O_{i}=\sum_{i}E_{i}=n∑i​Oi​=∑i​Ei​=n.
  • This approximation is Pearson’s chi-squared statistic PPP, and as it name suggests, when H0H_{0}H0​ is true, P≡∑i(Oi−Ei)2Ei≈χk−1−q2P \equiv \sum_{i} \frac{(O_{i}-E_{i})^{2}}{E_{i}} \approx \chi^{2}_{k-1-q}P≡i∑​Ei​(Oi​−Ei​)2​≈χk−1−q2​
  • Using P≈χk−1−q2P \approx \chi^{2}_{k-1-q}P≈χk−1−q2​ to test H0H_{0}H0​ is called Pearson’s chi-squared test.
    • Although the distribution is approximate, it usually gives the same result as LRT with the likelihood ratio statistic, if there are enough samples in each category.

Bayesian Statistics

Concepts and Definitions

  • Recall that Bayes’ theorem for discrete random variables X,YX,YX,Y states that P(X∣Y)=P(Y∣X)P(X)P(Y)\mathbb{P}(X|Y)=\frac{\mathbb{P}(Y|X)\mathbb{P}(X)}{\mathbb{P}(Y)}P(X∣Y)=P(Y)P(Y∣X)P(X)​and for continuous random variables X,YX,YX,Y with pdf. fXf_{X}fX​ and fYf_{Y}fY​, the conditional pdf is fX∣Y(x∣y)=fY∣X(y∣x)fX(x)fY(y)f_{X|Y}(x|y)=\frac{f_{Y|X}(y|x)f_{X}(x)}{f_{Y}(y)}fX∣Y​(x∣y)=fY​(y)fY∣X​(y∣x)fX​(x)​where fA∣B(a∣b)=fA,B(a,b)/f(b)f_{A|B}(a|b)=f_{A,B}(a,b) / f(b)fA∣B​(a∣b)=fA,B​(a,b)/f(b).
  • In Bayesian inference, parameter(s) is treated as a variable instead of a fixed value. Suppose we are estimating parameter θ\thetaθ from data X=x\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{x}X=x.
  • The assumed distribution of the parameter before any data is seen is called the prior (distribution) π(θ)\pi(\theta)π(θ).
  • After collecting data, the updated distribution of θ\thetaθ is a new distribution called the posterior (distribution) π(θ∣x)\pi (\theta|\mathbf{x})π(θ∣x).
    priorundefinedand updateobserve dataposterior\text{prior} \xrightarrow[\text{and update}]{\text{observe data}}\text{posterior}priorobserve dataand update​posterior
  • The “update” on the prior is done via Bayes’ theorem: π(θ∣x)=f(x∣θ)π(θ)f(x)=f(x∣θ)π(θ)∫Rf(x∣θ)π(θ) dx\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x})=\frac{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta)\pi(\theta)} {f(\mathbf{x})}=\frac{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta)\pi(\theta)}{\int _{\mathbb{R}} f(\mathbf{x}|\theta)\pi(\theta) \, dx }π(θ∣x)=f(x)f(x∣θ)π(θ)​=∫R​f(x∣θ)π(θ)dxf(x∣θ)π(θ)​and since the denominator f(x)f(\mathbf{x})f(x) is just a constant in Bayesian context, π(θ∣x)posterior∝f(x∣θ)likelihood×π(θ)prior\underset{\text{posterior}}{\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x})} \propto \underset{\text{likelihood}}{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta)} \times \underset{\text{prior}}{\pi(\theta)}posteriorπ(θ∣x)​∝likelihoodf(x∣θ)​×priorπ(θ)​

Conjugate Priors and Likelihoods

  • Conjugate pairs of likelihoods and priors generate posteriors that are in the same family as the priors: PriorLikelihoodNormalNormalBetaBinomial, GeometricGammaPoisson, Exponential\begin{array}{c|c} \text{Prior} & \text{Likelihood} \\ \hline \text{Normal} & \text{Normal} \\ \text{Beta} & \text{Binomial, Geometric} \\ \text{Gamma} & \text{Poisson, Exponential} \end{array}PriorNormalBetaGamma​LikelihoodNormalBinomial, GeometricPoisson, Exponential​​This is convenient because the parameters of the posterior can then be identified from f(x∣θ)×π(θ)f(\mathbf{x}|\theta)\times\pi(\theta)f(x∣θ)×π(θ). This determines the posterior without finding f(x)f(\mathbf{x})f(x) by integration.
  • For example, in studying the number of heads in coin flipping ∼Binom(n,p)\sim\mathrm{Binom}(n,p)∼Binom(n,p) with p=P[head]p=\mathbb{P}[\text{head}]p=P[head] unknown, choosing a Beta(α,β)\text{Beta}(\alpha,\beta)Beta(α,β) prior makes algebra easier.
  • The gamma distribution Γ(α,β)\Gamma(\alpha, \beta)Γ(α,β) with parameters shape=α>0\text{shape}=\alpha>0shape=α>0, rate=β>0\text{rate}=\beta>0rate=β>0 has density function fα,β(x)=βαΓ(α)xα−1e−βx,  x>0f_{\alpha,\beta}(x)=\frac{\beta^{\alpha}}{\Gamma(\alpha)}x^{\alpha-1}e^{-\beta x},\,\,x >0fα,β​(x)=Γ(α)βα​xα−1e−βx,x>0in particular, Γ(1,β)=exp⁡(β)\Gamma(1,\beta)=\exp(\beta)Γ(1,β)=exp(β).
    • Gamma is the sum of exponentials: if α\alphaα is an integer, X1,…,Xα∼iid.exp⁡(β)X_{1},\dots,X_{\alpha} \overset{iid.}{\sim}\exp(\beta)X1​,…,Xα​∼iid.exp(β), then ∑iXi∼Γ(α,β)\sum_{i}X_{i} \sim \Gamma(\alpha,\beta)∑i​Xi​∼Γ(α,β).
  • The gamma prior λ∼Γ(α,β)\lambda \sim \Gamma(\alpha, \beta)λ∼Γ(α,β) conjugates with a Poisson likelihood X1,…,Xn∼iid.Po(λ)X_{1},\dots,X_{n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} \mathrm{Po}(\lambda)X1​,…,Xn​∼iid.Po(λ): ↑βαΓ(α)λα−1e−βλundefinedgamma prior ⋅ ↑∏k=1n(λxkxk!e−λ)undefinedPoisson likelihood∝  λα+∑kxk−1e−(β+n)λ⟹  Γ(α+∑kxk,β+n)undefinedgamma posterior\begin{align*} \underbrace{\vphantom{\Bigg \uparrow}\frac{\beta^{\alpha}}{\Gamma(\alpha)}\lambda^{\alpha-1}e^{-\beta \lambda}}_{{\text{gamma prior}}} \,\cdot \, &\underbrace{\vphantom{\Bigg \uparrow}\prod^{n}_{k=1}\left(\frac{\lambda^{x_{k}}}{x_{k}!}e^{-\lambda}\right)}_{{\text{Poisson likelihood}}}\\ \\ \propto&\,\, {\lambda^{\alpha+\sum_{k}x_{k}-1}e^{-(\beta+n)\lambda}}\\ \\ \Longrightarrow& \,\,\underbrace{\Gamma\left( \alpha+\sum_{k}x_{k},\beta+n \right)}_{\text{gamma posterior}} \end{align*}gamma prior⏐↑​Γ(α)βα​λα−1e−βλ​​⋅∝⟹​Poisson likelihood⏐↑​k=1∏n​(xk​!λxk​​e−λ)​​λα+∑k​xk​−1e−(β+n)λgamma posteriorΓ(α+k∑​xk​,β+n)​​​
  • The beta distribution B(α,β)B(\alpha,\beta)B(α,β) has density function fα,β(x)=1B(α,β)xα−1(1−x)β−1f_{\alpha,\beta}(x)=\frac{1}{B(\alpha,\beta)}x^{\alpha-1}(1-x)^{\beta-1}fα,β​(x)=B(α,β)1​xα−1(1−x)β−1where BBB is the beta function.
  • The beta prior p∼B(α,β)p \sim B(\alpha,\beta)p∼B(α,β) conjugates with the binomial likelihood X∼Binom(n,p)X\sim \mathrm{Binom}(n,p)X∼Binom(n,p): ↑1B(α,β)pα−1(1−p)β−1undefinedbeta prior⋅↑(nx)px(1−p)n−xundefinedbinomial likelihood∝  p(α+x)−1(1−p)(β+n−x)−1⟹  B(α+x,β+n−x)undefinedbeta posterior\begin{align*} \underbrace{\vphantom{\Bigg \uparrow}\frac{1}{B(\alpha,\beta)}p^{\alpha-1}(1-p)^{\beta-1}}_{\text{beta prior}} &\cdot \underbrace{\vphantom{\Bigg \uparrow}{n\choose x}p^{x}(1-p)^{n-x} }_{{\text{binomial likelihood}}}\\ \\ \propto &\,\,p^{(\alpha+x)-1}(1-p)^{(\beta+n-x)-1}\\ \\ \Longrightarrow&\,\, \underbrace{B(\alpha+x, \beta+n-x)}_{\text{beta posterior}} \end{align*}beta prior⏐↑​B(α,β)1​pα−1(1−p)β−1​​∝⟹​⋅binomial likelihood⏐↑​(xn​)px(1−p)n−x​​p(α+x)−1(1−p)(β+n−x)−1beta posteriorB(α+x,β+n−x)​​​

Interpretations of Conjugates

  • Certain priors can be interpreted as previously conducted experiments, to be combined with new evidence.

  • A gamma prior λ∼Γ(α,β)\lambda \sim\Gamma(\alpha,\beta)λ∼Γ(α,β) conjugating with X1,…,Xn∼iid.Po(λ)X_{1},\dots,X_{n} \overset{iid.}{\sim} \mathrm{Po}(\lambda)X1​,…,Xn​∼iid.Po(λ) can be interpreted as a Poisson process counting the number of distinct events: Prior λ∼Γ(α,β):α occurances of β distinct eventsLikelihood of X1,…,n:∑kxk occurances of n other events \begin{align*} &\text{Prior } \lambda \sim\Gamma(\alpha,\beta): && \alpha \text{ occurances of } \beta \text{ distinct events}\\ &\text{Likelihood of } X_{1,\dots,n}: &&\sum_{k}x_{k} \text{ occurances of }n \text{ other events} \end{align*}​Prior λ∼Γ(α,β):Likelihood of X1,…,n​:​​α occurances of β distinct eventsk∑​xk​ occurances of n other events​and the posterior Γ(α+∑kxk,β+n)\Gamma\left( \alpha+\sum_{k}x_{k}, \beta+n\right)Γ(α+∑k​xk​,β+n) is just the “sum” of the two.

  • Similarly, a beta prior λ∼B(α,β)\lambda \sim B(\alpha,\beta)λ∼B(α,β) conjugating with X∼Binomial(n,λ)X \sim \mathrm{Binomial}(n,\lambda)X∼Binomial(n,λ) can be interpreted as previous Binomial/Bernoulli trials: Prior λ∼B(α,β):α−1 successes and β−1 failures seenLikelihood of X:X=x successes in n more trials\begin{align*} &\text{Prior } \lambda \sim B(\alpha,\beta): && \alpha-1 \text{ successes and }\beta-1 \text{ failures seen}\\ &\text{Likelihood of } X: &&X=x \text{ successes in }n \text{ more trials} \end{align*}​Prior λ∼B(α,β):Likelihood of X:​​α−1 successes and β−1 failures seenX=x successes in n more trials​so the posterior B(α+x,β+n−x)B(\alpha+x, \beta+n-x)B(α+x,β+n−x) records +x+x+x successes and +(n−x)+(n-x)+(n−x) failures.

Uninformative and Jefferys Priors

  • In cases where we have no prior information, uninformative/objective priors can represent ignorance, e.g. a p∼U[0,1]p \sim U[0,1]p∼U[0,1] for the probability in Bernoulli(p)\text{Bernoulli}(p)Bernoulli(p).
    • Following the interpretations in the previous section, “no previous experiments” correspond to B(1,1)=U[0,1]B(1,1)=U[0,1]B(1,1)=U[0,1].
  • However, for parameters without bounds, e.g. the mean μ\muμ in N(μ,σ2)N(\mu,\sigma^{2})N(μ,σ2), an ignorant prior would be U(−∞,∞)U(-\infty,\infty)U(−∞,∞), which cannot be normalized to have integral 111. In those cases, they are called improper priors.
    • Improper priors can still produce proper posteriors, so they are not an issue per se.
  • Another issue is that in general, reparametrization does not preserve uninformativeness: given prior π(θ)\pi(\theta)π(θ) and transformation ϕ=g(θ)\phi=g(\theta)ϕ=g(θ), its reparametrized distribution is p(ϕ)=π(g−1(ϕ))∣dθdϕ∣p(\phi)=\pi(g^{-1}(\phi)) \left| \frac{d\theta}{d\phi}\right|p(ϕ)=π(g−1(ϕ))∣∣​dϕdθ​∣∣​which is not necessarily uninformative.
  • For example, suppose ϕ∼U[0,1]\phi \sim U[0,1]ϕ∼U[0,1] (left), then under a log-odds map ϕ→ψ=log⁡(ϕ/(1−ϕ))\phi \to \psi=\log(\phi / (1-\phi))ϕ→ψ=log(ϕ/(1−ϕ)),
    the log-odds (right) is bell-shaped, concentrated within [−3,3][-3,3][−3,3]. It’s no longer “ignorant”.
  • Jefferys priors are priors that are resistant to reparametrization, defined by π(θ)∝∣Iθ(θ)∣\pi(\theta)\propto \sqrt{ |I_{\theta}(\theta)| }π(θ)∝∣Iθ​(θ)∣​where Iθ(θ)I_{\theta}(\theta)Iθ​(θ) is the expected/Fisher information of θ\thetaθ.
  • Jefferys priors are resistant in the sense that it is always proportional to the root-information: if π(θ)\pi(\theta)π(θ) is a Jefferys prior, then p(ϕ)=π(g−1(ϕ))∣g′(ϕ)∣∝∣Iϕ(ϕ)∣p(\phi)=\pi(g^{-1}(\phi))|g'(\phi)| \propto \sqrt{ |I_{\phi}(\phi)| }p(ϕ)=π(g−1(ϕ))∣g′(ϕ)∣∝∣Iϕ​(ϕ)∣​note that IϕI_{\phi}Iϕ​ is the expected information of ϕ\phiϕ, averaged over ϕ\phiϕ, not θ\thetaθ.
  • Common Jefferys priors include:
    • π(θ)∝1\pi(\theta)\propto1π(θ)∝1, where θ\thetaθ is a location parameter, e.g. the mean of N(θ,σ2)N(\theta,\sigma^{2})N(θ,σ2), or the lower bound of U[θ,θ+1]U[\theta,\theta+1]U[θ,θ+1].
    • π(σ)∝1σ\pi(\sigma)\propto \frac{1}{\sigma}π(σ)∝σ1​, where σ\sigmaσ is a scale parameter, e.g. the standard deviation σ\sigmaσ of N(θ,σ2)N(\theta,\sigma^{2})N(θ,σ2).

Bayesian Inference

The section titled Posterior summaries in section 4.24.24.2 of the notes is omitted, as it is just computing common summary statistics.

Credible Intervals

Big idea: credible intervals are the Bayesian equivalent of confidence intervals.

  • A 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)% credible set is any set C⊆ΘC \subseteq \ThetaC⊆Θ that the probability of θ∣x\theta | \mathbf{x}θ∣x being in it is 100(1−α)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1−α)%: C:∫Cπ(θ∣x) dx=1−αC: \int _{C} \pi(\theta|\mathbf{x}) \, dx =1-\alphaC:∫C​π(θ∣x)dx=1−α
  • The difference between the Bayesian credible interval CCC and the frequentist confidence interval III is just what is considered variable: Bayesian:variable θ∣x has probability ... to be in C. Frequentist:variable I(x) has probability ... to contain θ.\begin{align*} &\text{Bayesian:} &&\text{variable $\theta|\mathbf{x}$ has probability ... to be in $C$. }\\ &\text{Frequentist:} &&\text{variable $I(\mathbf{x})$ has probability ... to contain $\theta$.} \end{align*}​Bayesian:Frequentist:​​variable θ∣x has probability ... to be in C. variable I(x) has probability ... to contain θ.​
  • A credible interval (θ1,θ2)(\theta_{1},\theta_{2})(θ1​,θ2​) is just a credible set that is also an interval.
  • A credible interval is equal-tailed if P(θ∣x≤θ1)=P(θ∣x≥θ1)\mathbb{P}(\theta|\mathbf{x} \le \theta_{1})=\mathbb{P}(\theta|\mathbf{x} \ge \theta_{1})P(θ∣x≤θ1​)=P(θ∣x≥θ1​); for example, the two highlighted tails have equal area:
  • A credible set/interval CCC is highest posterior density (HPD) if it has the form C={θ:π(θ∣x)≥pmin⁡}C = \{ \theta:\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x}) \ge p_{\min} \}C={θ:π(θ∣x)≥pmin​}for some constant pmin⁡p_{\min}pmin​. Equivalently, C:∀θ∈C,θ′∉C,π(θ∣x)>π(θ′∣x)C:\forall \theta \in C, \theta' \not \in C, \pi(\theta|\mathbf{x})>\pi(\theta'|\mathbf{x})C:∀θ∈C,θ′∈C,π(θ∣x)>π(θ′∣x)For example, the highlight region is an HPD set, where pmin⁡p_{\min}pmin​ is the horizontal line:

Prediction with the Posterior

  • Given observations X=(X1,…,Xn)\mathbf{X}=(X_{1},\dots,X_{n})X=(X1​,…,Xn​) and the posterior θ∼π(θ∣x)\theta \sim\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x})θ∼π(θ∣x) computed from them, the (posterior) predictive density of a new observation Xn+1X_{n+1}Xn+1​ is f(Xn+1∣x)f(X_{n+1}|\mathbf{x})f(Xn+1​∣x).
    • That is, our updated belief about the underlying distribution fff, after incorporating the knowledge from previous data x\mathbf{x}x.
  • The predictive density can be computed by: f(Xn+1∣x)=∫f(Xn+1,θ∣x) dθdefinition of marginal density=∫f(Xn+1∣θ,x) ⋅ π(θ∣x) dθBayes’ rule=∫f(Xn+1∣θ)prediction ⋅ π(θ∣x)posterior dθindependence of Xn+1 and x=(x1,…,xn)\begin{align*} f(X_{n+1}|\mathbf{x})&= \int f(X_{n+1},\theta|\mathbf{x}) \, d\theta &&\substack{\text{definition of }\\\text{marginal density}}\\ &= \int f(X_{n+1}|\theta,\mathbf{x}) \,\cdot\,\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x}) \, d\theta &&\text{Bayes' rule}\\ &= \int \underset{\text{prediction}}{f(X_{n+1}|\theta)} \,\cdot\, \underset{\text{posterior}}{\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x})} \, d\theta &&\substack{\text{independence of } X_{n+1} \\\text{ and } \mathbf{x}=(x_{1},\dots,x_{n})} \end{align*}f(Xn+1​∣x)​=∫f(Xn+1​,θ∣x)dθ=∫f(Xn+1​∣θ,x)⋅π(θ∣x)dθ=∫predictionf(Xn+1​∣θ)​⋅posteriorπ(θ∣x)​dθ​​definition of marginal density​Bayes’ ruleindependence of Xn+1​ and x=(x1​,…,xn​)​​i.e. the prediction averaged over the posterior.

Bayesian Hypothesis Testing

General Bayesian Testing

This is in the notes for some reason, but I don’t think it will be tested…

  • The most general setup of Bayesian tests has the form: H0:  X∼f(x;θ0),where θ0∈Θ0 has prior π(θ0)H1:  X∼g(x;θ1),where θ1∈Θ1 has prior τ(θ1)\begin{align*} H_{0}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim f(\mathbf{x};\theta_{0}), && \text{where }\theta_{0} \in \Theta_{0} \text{ has prior }\pi(\theta_{0})\\ H_{1}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim g(\mathbf{x};\theta_{1}) , &&\text{where }\theta_{1} \in \Theta_{1} \text{ has prior } \tau(\theta_{1}) \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​X∼f(x;θ0​),X∼g(x;θ1​),​​where θ0​∈Θ0​ has prior π(θ0​)where θ1​∈Θ1​ has prior τ(θ1​)​For this kind of general setup, the prior probabilities can only be manually assigned, with P(H0)+P(H1)=1\mathbb{P}(H_{0})+\mathbb{P}(H_{1})=1P(H0​)+P(H1​)=1.

  • In general, f,gf,gf,g and π,τ\pi,\tauπ,τ can be different (families of) distributions, and Θ0,1\Theta_{0,1}Θ0,1​ different parameter spaces, for example: H0:  X∼exp⁡(θ0),where θ0∈R+ has prior Γ(α,β)H1:  X∼χ2(θ1),where θ1∈Z+ has prior p(n)=n−1\begin{align*} H_{0}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim \exp(\theta_{0}) ,&&\text{where }\theta_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{+} \text{ has prior }\Gamma(\alpha,\beta)\\ H_{1}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim \chi^{2}(\theta_{1}) ,&&\text{where }\theta_{1} \in \mathbb{Z}^{+} \text{ has prior } p(n)=n^{-1} \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​X∼exp(θ0​),X∼χ2(θ1​),​​where θ0​∈R+ has prior Γ(α,β)where θ1​∈Z+ has prior p(n)=n−1​

  • A special case is when f=gf=gf=g are the same distribution, and there is a shared prior π(θ)\pi(\theta)π(θ). Here H0,H1H_{0},H_{1}H0​,H1​ also have disjoint parameter spaces Θ0,Θ1\Theta_{0},\Theta_{1}Θ0​,Θ1​: H0:  X∼f(x;θ),θ∈Θ0 has prior π(θ∣H0)=π(θ)∣Θ0P(H0)H1:  X∼f(x;θ),θ∈Θ1 has prior π(θ∣H1)=π(θ)∣Θ1P(H1)\begin{align*} H_{0}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim f(\mathbf{x};\theta), && \theta \in \Theta_{0} \text{ has prior }\pi(\theta|H_{0})=\frac{\pi(\theta)|_{\Theta_{0}}}{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}\\ H_{1}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim f(\mathbf{x};\theta) , && \theta \in \Theta_{1} \text{ has prior }\pi(\theta|H_{1})=\frac{\pi(\theta)|_{\Theta_{1}}}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1})} \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​X∼f(x;θ),X∼f(x;θ),​​θ∈Θ0​ has prior π(θ∣H0​)=P(H0​)π(θ)∣Θ0​​​θ∈Θ1​ has prior π(θ∣H1​)=P(H1​)π(θ)∣Θ1​​​​where the π∣Θi\pi|_{\Theta_{i}}π∣Θi​​ means "restricted to Θi\Theta_{i}Θi​". Given the shared prior, we can compute the prior probabilities: P(Hi)=∫Θiπ(θ) dx\mathbb{P}(H_{i})=\int _{\Theta_{i}} \pi(\theta) \, dx P(Hi​)=∫Θi​​π(θ)dx

  • For example, with prior π(θ)=U(0,3]\pi(\theta)=U(0,3]π(θ)=U(0,3], parameter spaces Θ0=(0,2]\Theta_{0}=(0,2]Θ0​=(0,2], Θ1=(2,3]\Theta_{1}=(2,3]Θ1​=(2,3], we can have hypotheses H0:  X∼exp⁡(θ),where θ∈(0,2] has prior U(0,2]H1:  X∼exp⁡(θ),where θ∈(2,3] has prior U(2,3]\begin{align*} H_{0}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim \exp(\theta) ,&&\text{where }\theta \in (0,2] \text{ has prior } U(0,2]\\ H_{1}:\,\, &\mathbf{X} \sim \exp(\theta) ,&&\text{where }\theta \in (2,3] \text{ has prior } U(2,3] \end{align*}H0​:H1​:​X∼exp(θ),X∼exp(θ),​​where θ∈(0,2] has prior U(0,2]where θ∈(2,3] has prior U(2,3]​where the prior probabilities are P(H0)=2/3\mathbb{P}(H_{0})=2 / 3P(H0​)=2/3, and P(H1)=1/3\mathbb{P}(H_{1})=1 / 3P(H1​)=1/3.

Odds

  • In this section, we only consider hypothesis tests with composite hypotheses H0:θ∈Θ0H_{0}:\theta \in \Theta_{0}H0​:θ∈Θ0​ and H1=H0CH_{1}=H_{0}^{C}H1​=H0C​.

  • For an event AAA, its odds is odds(A)=P(A)1−P(A)\text{odds}(A)=\frac{\mathbb{P}(A)}{1-\mathbb{P}(A)}odds(A)=1−P(A)P(A)​

  • In Bayesian statistics, parameters are treated as variables, so H0:θ∈Θ0H_{0}:\theta \in \Theta_{0}H0​:θ∈Θ0​ is an event, and can be assigned a prior probability P(H0)\mathbb{P}(H_{0})P(H0​); similarly for H1H_{1}H1​.

  • The odds of H0H_{0}H0​ is then prior odds=P(H0)1−P(H0)=P(H0)P(H1)\text{prior odds}=\frac{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}{1-\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}=\frac{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1})}prior odds=1−P(H0​)P(H0​)​=P(H1​)P(H0​)​this is the prior odds of H0H_{0}H0​ to H1H_{1}H1​.

  • After observing data x\mathbf{x}x, the posterior probability P(H0∣x)\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x})P(H0​∣x) is the Bayesian equivalent of the p-value, which again has different interpretations: Bayesian P(H0∣x):probability that H0 is true, given x.Frequentist p-value:probability of seeing x, given H0.\begin{align*} &\text{Bayesian }\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x}): &&\text{probability that $H_{0}$ is true, given $\mathbf{x}$.}\\ &\text{Frequentist p-value:} &&\text{probability of seeing $\mathbf{x}$, given $H_{0}$.} \end{align*}​Bayesian P(H0​∣x):Frequentist p-value:​​probability that H0​ is true, given x.probability of seeing x, given H0​.​accoringly, the posterior odds are posterior odds=P(H0∣x)P(H1∣x)\text{posterior odds}=\frac{\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x})}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1}|\mathbf{x})}posterior odds=P(H1​∣x)P(H0​∣x)​and applying Bayes theorem to P(Hi∣x)\mathbb{P}(H_{i}|\mathbf{x})P(Hi​∣x) gives: P(H0∣x)P(H1∣x)posterior odds=P(x∣H0)P(H0)/P(x)P(x∣H1)P(H1)/P(x)=P(x∣H0)P(x∣H1)Bayesian factor⋅ P(H0)P(H1)prior odds\underset{\text{posterior odds}}{\frac{\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x})}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1}|\mathbf{x})}}=\frac{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{0})\mathbb{P}(H_{0}) / \mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x})}{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{1})\mathbb{P}(H_{1}) / \mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x})}=\underset{\text{Bayesian factor}}{\frac{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{1})}}\cdot\,\underset{\text{prior odds}}{\frac{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1})}}posterior oddsP(H1​∣x)P(H0​∣x)​​=P(x∣H1​)P(H1​)/P(x)P(x∣H0​)P(H0​)/P(x)​=Bayesian factorP(x∣H1​)P(x∣H0​)​​⋅prior oddsP(H1​)P(H0​)​​

The Bayesian Factor

  • In previous equation, the only part dependent on x\mathbf{x}x is the Bayesian factor, which compares how consistent H0H_{0}H0​ and H1H_{1}H1​ are with the data: composite hypothesesH0:θ∈Θ0,  H1:θ∈Θ1 Bayesian factor B01≡P(x∣H0)P(x∣H1)\underset{H_{0}:\theta \in \Theta_{0},\,\,H_{1}:\theta \in \Theta_{1}}{\text{composite hypotheses}} {\text{ Bayesian factor }}B_{01} \equiv\frac{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{1})}H0​:θ∈Θ0​,H1​:θ∈Θ1​composite hypotheses​ Bayesian factor B01​≡P(x∣H1​)P(x∣H0​)​The numerator and denominator are the marginal likelihoods (of H0,1H_{0,1}H0,1​), and B01B_{01}B01​ the Bayesian equivalent of the likelihood ratio.
  • If H0H_{0}H0​ or both H0,1H_{0,1}H0,1​ are simple hypotheses, their probability P(x∣Hi)\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{i})P(x∣Hi​) is replaced with the distribution function: simple hypothesesH0:θ=θ0,  H1:θ=θ1 Bayesian factor =f(x∣θ0)f(x∣θ1)mixed hypothesesH0:θ=θ0,  H1:θ∈Θ1 Bayesian factor =f(x∣θ0)P(x∣H1)\begin{align*} \underset{H_{0}:\theta = \theta_{0},\,\,H_{1}:\theta=\theta_{1}}{\text{simple hypotheses}} {\text{ Bayesian factor }} &= \frac{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta_{0})}{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta_{1})}\\ \underset{H_{0}:\theta = \theta_{0},\,\,H_{1}:\theta \in \Theta_{1}}{\text{mixed hypotheses}} {\text{ Bayesian factor }}&= \frac{f(\mathbf{x}|\theta_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{1})} \end{align*}H0​:θ=θ0​,H1​:θ=θ1​simple hypotheses​ Bayesian factor H0​:θ=θ0​,H1​:θ∈Θ1​mixed hypotheses​ Bayesian factor ​=f(x∣θ1​)f(x∣θ0​)​=P(x∣H1​)f(x∣θ0​)​​

Computing the Bayes Factor

This section only cover cases where H0H_{0}H0​ and H1H_{1}H1​ use the same model f(x;θ)f(\mathbf{x};\theta)f(x;θ), as do the examples 4.11∼4.134.11\sim 4.134.11∼4.13 in the 2022-2023 notes.

  • The Bayes factor is useful for interpreting the evidence, where a large factor means evidences in favor of H0H_{0}H0​.

  • One way to compute the factor is to use the formula B01=posterior oddsprior oddsB_{01}=\frac{\text{posterior odds}}{\text{prior odds}}B01​=prior oddsposterior odds​:

    • compute the prior odds, from P(H0)/P(H1)\mathbb{P}(H_{0}) / \mathbb{P}(H_{1})P(H0​)/P(H1​) if they are given (example 4.114.114.11) or from a shared prior (example 4.124.124.12).
    • compute the posterior probability of H0H_{0}H0​: P(H0∣x)=∫Θ0π(θ∣x) dθ=∫Θ0(posterior of θ) dθ\mathbb{P}(H_{0}| \mathbf{x})=\int _{\Theta_{0}}\pi(\theta|\mathbf{x}) \, d\theta=\int _{\Theta_{0}} (\text{posterior of }\theta) \, d\thetaP(H0​∣x)=∫Θ0​​π(θ∣x)dθ=∫Θ0​​(posterior of θ)dθand hence the posterior odds P(H0∣x)/(1−P(H0∣x))\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x}) / (1-\mathbb{P}(H_{0}|\mathbf{x}))P(H0​∣x)/(1−P(H0​∣x)).

  • Another way to compute it is directly use the definitions and plugin the marginal likelihoods (second half of example 4.134.134.13): B01≡P(x∣H0)P(x∣H1)=[∫Θ0f(x;θ)π(θ∣H0) dθP(H0)]/[∫Θ1f(x;θ)π(θ∣H1) dθP(H1)]=[∫Θ0likelihood ⋅prior0 dθP(H0)]/[∫Θ1likelihood ⋅prior1dθP(H1)]\begin{align*} B_{01} &\equiv\frac{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{0})}{\mathbb{P}(\mathbf{x}|H_{1})}\\ &= \left[\frac{{\int _{\Theta_{0}}f(\mathbf{x};\theta) \pi(\theta|H_{0})\, d\theta }}{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}\right] \Big/ \left[\frac{{\int _{\Theta_{1}}f(\mathbf{x};\theta) \pi(\theta|H_{1})\, d\theta }}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1})}\right]\\ &= \left[\frac{{\int _{\Theta_{0}}\text{likelihood }\cdot \text{prior}_{0}\, d\theta }}{\mathbb{P}(H_{0})}\right] \Big/ \left[\frac{{\int _{\Theta_{1}}\text{likelihood }\cdot \text{prior}_{1} d\theta }}{\mathbb{P}(H_{1})}\right] \end{align*}B01​​≡P(x∣H1​)P(x∣H0​)​=[P(H0​)∫Θ0​​f(x;θ)π(θ∣H0​)dθ​]/[P(H1​)∫Θ1​​f(x;θ)π(θ∣H1​)dθ​]=[P(H0​)∫Θ0​​likelihood ⋅prior0​dθ​]/[P(H1​)∫Θ1​​likelihood ⋅prior1​dθ​]​
